text: [Music]
hello everyone we are antonio de la piedra and malus venema and we will present for you practical attacks
against attribute-based encryption so first let me start a little bit with the motivation
so attribute based encryption or abe for short is a type of public key encryption
in which the keys are associated with attributes and this is in contrast to a traditional
public key encryption in which key pairs are often associated with individuals so
with one person um because it allows for the enforcement of access control
on a cryptographic level it's often a very popular primitive in settings such
as iot or cloud settings in which we cannot store the data on a trusted platform
actually what we've seen is that many schemes have been designed and several very popular schemes have
also been broken in literature and in this talk we will show that the implementations of these schemes are
also broken in particular the three schemes that we will consider in this log are the yct 14
the duck max and the white j14 schemes now to give a little bit of an overview
of this talk we will first start a little bit about um what is attribute-based encryption what
can we do with attribute-based encryption um how is abe is constructed in general
um how some of the schemes that have been designed fail in theory how these attacks carry over to practice and then
we show um that these implementations of these schemes are also broken
now on a higher level there are two variants of abe namely key policy and cipher text policy abe or kp abe and
cpaba for short and yct 14 is a kp ebc kp abe scheme and
dac max and yj14 are cp abe schemes in this talk we will mainly focus on
cpave um and also duck max because it's the simplest attack
um but maybe also a little bit because cp abe is slightly more popular for practical applications than kpip
to mention the main distinction between these types of abe is in which
the policy is applied to the keys or the cipher text hence the naming of it now let's consider the general
setting of abe so like in traditional public key encryption we often consider
a setting with alice and bob in which both of them might want to communicate and they do not want to know
they do not want that if some eavesdropper knows what they're talking about so for
instance they can use encryption to do that and then cpabe we also have two other entities namely
the cloud also the key generation authority and this key generation authority or kga for
short generates a master key pair consisting of a master secret key and a master public key and much like
traditional public key encryption this master public key is shared with anyone who wants to
decrypt so for in this case alice and
the master secret key is used to generate secret keys for users so in this case for instance bob
is a doctor at the mayo clinic and neurology department and then he can request keys for such attributes
now once alice wants to encrypt her data she can think about who she wants to share this data with so in traditional
public key encryption we would grab the public key of the receiver but in this case she could
specify a policy so for instance she wants to share her data with doctors or nurses at the mayo clinic in the
neurology department she can specify that in the policy encrypt the data under that policy and
then put it in the cloud now once this data is in the cloud bob can actually decrypt it because he has a
secret key that satisfies the policy because he's a doctor at the mayo clinic in the neurology department
and importantly charlie who is a nurse in the radiology department cannot decrypt it because he
does not satisfy the policy and this also implies already a security notion so
even though you have secret keys you might not be able to decrypt the cipher text because you do not have a set of
attributes that satisfies the policy now note that we considered
a single key generation authority in the previous slide but we can also imagine that we have
settings with the hospital with the insurance company in which we have multiple uh
yeah domains with different trust assumptions so for instance people at the hospital may not
necessarily trust everyone at insurance companies and vice versa
and in that case we can use multi-authority abe and these different domains can also
assign different key generation authorities in this case we would have a key generation authority for a hospital and
one for an insurance company and now ellis can also use the public keys of both key generation authorities
while maybe not all decrypting users have keys for all of the authorities
and this also implies a notion of security because like i just said
the hospital may not trust the insurance company the insurance company may not trust the hospital
but also bob for instance may not trust the insurance company and only the hospital so this sort of implies a level of trust
and essentially an abe we model this kind of trust by
proofing security against corrupted authorities so this essentially means that even though one or more authorities
may be corrupt this should not impede the security of the honest authority
in the next section i will describe which are the applications of attribute-based encryption in
relationship with the cloud and internet of things in the case of the cloud attribute-based
encryption is normally used as an authorization mechanism that means that data owners for instance alice will
create encryption keys that are used to protect content like
media or has records these keys can be protected using an access policy and
then only users like for instance but charlie can decrypt the cipher text only
if they have it they can fulfill this
access policies so one of the schemes that have been proposed for
protecting the cloud using abe is the duckmaster scheme
publishes effective data access control for multi-authority cloud storage
systems this is a scheme that is highly cited in academia has
has been analyzed and one of the european projects of the original 2020 framework called asclepius
in the next slide you can see the architecture of the scheme so there are mainly five

the master of global attribute authority that has mainly two methods user registration and attribute registration
concerning the attribute authorities in this example you can see too you can see the insurance company attribute

these entities will give the attributes to the users together with secret keys that the users can use later on to
decrypt data so here the data owner is alice alice will take will generate the content keys
these keys are used to encrypt sensitive data like like health records or media
and this keys will be encrypted according to an access policy then both encrypted content keys and
the data and encrypted data will be put into the cloud and then the users using the secret keys
can be involved into a token generation process so only if they can fulfill the access policy
they can decrypt the data
one iteration of dac max is the yg14 scheme published at the ieee transactions of parallel and disabled
systems as expressive efficient and revocable data access control for multi-authority cloud storage this is
considered an improved version of dac max however is also broken and the main difference
is that the token generation process disappears so in the next slides you can see the

directly to the cloud take the cipher text and if they can fulfill the access policies
then they can access the data sorry the content is that they can use to decrypt the data
concerning iot normally authors work with the concept of smart city so that means that there

used to enforce authorization to the collected data um for different data owners and analysts
according to their responsibility another domain
concerning iot is the health and medical monitoring so in this case abe could be used to enforce access control to the
different parties involved by for instance doctors nurses or people like passions
one of the schemes that has been proposed for enforcing authorization on the iot setting is the
ict 14 scheme this is a scheme that was published as
the future generation computer system journal as a lightweight attribute-based encryption scheme for the internet of
things this is a single authority scheme and is based on electrical cryptography since it is
designed with iot in mind this is in a way designed to support a
distributed environment and to provide secure data transmission
now let me talk about the components of abe and in particular i want to talk about
elliptic curves bearings and secret chair now elliptic curves are groups um
generated by some generator g of primordity and typically we use these elliptic curves um if we assume for
these elliptic curves that some problem is hard so in this case for instance the elliptic curve decisional diffie-hellman
problem and this problem says that if we have two elements g to the power x t to the
power of y and also an element z that's in this group where x and y are integers
then we want to determine whether set is equal to g to the power x y and typically we assume that this is
difficult to do to to do this to determine this and then security of a scheme that we make
depends on this hardness and note that elliptic curves are additive in this stock we often use yeah in this
stock we use multiplicative notation because it's also often done in literature
now once we have defined the elliptic curve then it might be possible that we can define a pairing over them
so a pairing is an efficient mapping from an elliptic curve in a product with
itself to a target group gt and for this uh pairing operation e it
holds that some special property holds so if you take the pairing of t to the
power a and g to the power b then this is equal to taking this target group element e g g to the power a b
so essentially you can efficient this as a sort of exponentiation with an hidden
exponent so essentially you would exponentiate g to the power a here
with b without actually knowing this b so for instance if you consider
a traditional algomal encryption of a message m in which your secret key is this integer
y and your public key is g to the power of this integer y
and your ciphertext consists of this masking of message m with the public key
to the power x and g to the power x then you can decrypt by exponentiating
like the second part of the cipher text with your secret key and cancel this this masking
pk to the power x now if you want to take the pairing based version of it we could say for
instance the secret key is not an integer anymore but a group element so g to the power of y
and in this case we could take this public key to be a pairing group element so eg to the power of y
and then the ciphertext would look the same but in this case this
masking of the message is a target group element again um and then decryption would be a pairing
operation instead of an exponentiation and we will see that this
is actually very useful for abe because um now like
in the case of elgamal having group elements gives you certain security assumptions and it will become later
important in abe now at last i want to talk a little bit
about secret sharing and in secret sharing we consider how the sharing of a
secret s with respect to some access policy happens so a very simple example is an end gate
so for instance mayo clinic and neurology and you have the secret s that you want
to split into random secrets and you can do that by generating a random integer as one and then
subtracting it from the secret s and that will be your second secret sharing
and now note that you can only recover this as if you have both mayo clinic and neurology
and now if we put all of these three components together we can also create a toy example of an abe scheme and for
this it's not really important that you know all of the details but it's i wanted to show you just how an abe

so here you also see this and gate coming back and basically only if you compare
combine a secret key for attributes one and two with this

elements and your ciphertext as well and that's basically what i want you to
take away from it key generation and encryption considers just of generating a bunch of group elements so
not integers like in elgamal and decryption is a bunch of pairing operations
now i want to talk a little bit about ave schemes and how they fail in theory and
before i do that i want to talk about when they do not fail so basically an abe scheme is is good if
it's correct if it's secure and what does it mean for an abe scheme to be secure
well much like in traditional public key encryption we have this notion of indistinguishability
and the chosen plaintext attacks and this basically means that if an attacker chooses
any two messages and uh some challenger encrypts one of the two then the attacker should not be
able to know which one of the two was encrypted so basically if you know any of the
messages was encrypted you should not be able to learn anything
about whether one of the two was encrypted but in abe we also have a special notion
of collusion resistance and that basically means that decrypting users cannot collude so if they all have
their own secret keys and they cannot individually decrypt then they should not be able to do this together either
and of course um we want this notion of collusion resistance to hold for the indistinguishability and the chosen
plaintext attack so if if these decrypting users cannot mountain in
chosen plaintext attack alone then they shouldn't be able to do that together either and it actually holds for all abe all of
these abe schemes that exist need to be secure under these security notions
like i just said in the multi-authority abe setting we have we have like a different
notion of security even namely corruption and that needs to also hold so on top of
that so basically that means that we have the indistinguishability on the chosen plaintext attacks
and collusion resistance but with respect to the honest authorities if one or more authorities are corrupted
and actually these three security notions make it very difficult to prove abe secure
and it's actually so difficult that many schemes turn out to be broken so we have considered three works in our
